column4: gahhhh. i wish the other half would let me install a distro on the desktop :\
i am running an IBM T43 laptop booting off a USB hard drive :)  my internal HD is windows
i also ran ubuntu in vmware for a long time on my windows drive, you can run it full screen
no, not by default at least
what are you trying to accomplish?
nothing, really. i am thinking about moving partitions around and adding edgy to the mix
cool!  it mounted, but i can't even browse it due to permissions..?
>> try something like chmod 755 <dir>
failed due to read-only file system!
did you try the last one with sudo ?
yes
> if youre using gnome and want to view the files in nautilus, try  "sudo cd <mountpoint> && sudo gnome-open . "
'sudo cd <mount point>' gives: sudo: cd: command not found
gnome-open or gksudo nautilus results in an invisible sleeping nautilus instance...i;'m running feisty
>> with gnome-open, are you including the "." at the end of that command
a "."  ?  no
>> try again. "gnome-open ."   the . is important - it signifies the current directory
'gnome-open .'   opens a working nautilus in my current directory
'sudo gnome-open /media/ntfsvol' hangs
so the question is, how to unmount the currently mounting?
sudo umount <mountpoint>
